description.narrative: Output 1.4: Children and their families in humanitarian situations have timely and sustained access to quality health care services, which contributes to Child Health, Child Health (Covid), Immunization, Maternal And Newborn Health, Technical Excellence In Humanitarian Action. UNICEF aims to achieve this through Evaluations, Research And Data, Systems Strengthening And Institution Building. This contributes to the following Country Programme result: Outcome 1: Children, adolescents and women have equitable access to and use improved and quality, high-impact maternal, neonatal and child health interventions and adopt healthy life practices.

condition.narrative: Should contribute directly to results for children as outlined in the UNDAF, national results and/or UNICEF Strategic Plan and within the scope defined in the CPD, CPAP, OMP or other agreed upon programme documents

title.narrative: Output 1.4: Children and their families in humanitarian situations have timely and sustained access to quality health care services

description.narrative: UNICEF supported the State Primary Health Care Boards of Adamawa, Borno and Yobe to immunize 1,497,533 children against measles, enabled 4,342,190 OPD consultations through primary health care services, 9,160 newborns received postnatal care within two days and treated 79,526 children for acute respiratory infection, 253,568 for diarrhea and 121,812 for fever/malaria. | Status:On-track | As-of Date:31/12/2019

title.narrative: Number of UNICEF-targeted children under 2 years in humanitarian situations who are vaccinated against measles
Percentage of targeted people in humanitarian situations reached with emergency primary health care services
